Author: Áõ∏ÂéüËºùÂ§´
Review:
A shrine that enshrines the Onmyouji Abe no Seimei, and is enshrined in the ruins of Abe no Seimei's mansion.
It is a shrine that wards off evil, and there is a yakuyoke peach in the precincts. Peach is said to be a fruit that wards off evil. It is said that by rubbing the peach against the misfortune that you have in yourself, you will be able to ward off misfortune.
It's a small shrine, but it became popular after a novel that was made into a manga and a movie became a hit, and it seems that many young people especially visit the shrine.
My hobby is taking pictures of flowers (I live in Osaka Prefecture).
On this day (July 13, 2022), I visited to take pictures of bellflowers.
Seimei Shrine's crest is a five-pointed star, which is said to ward off evil spirits. It is said that it is also called "Seimei Kikyo", which is a design of the flower of the bellflower.
From the origin of such a company crest, it seems that bellflowers are planted in the precincts. I think it's a perfect shrine for the noble and beautiful image of the bellflower.
In addition, there was an omikuji (fortune slip) for this time (corona wreck), so I will introduce it (photo attached). It is a non-contact omikuji, and when you wave your hand toward the sensor, the Shikigami tells you the number from the screen (computer). It may be my lack of knowledge, but this is the first time I've seen an omikuji like this.

Author: KOJI
Review:
When I first visited the shrine, I thought it was a small but nasty shrine because of the store-like goods sales area in front of the shrine and the autographs of celebrities.

This is a special place among the many shrines in Kyoto.
Thanks to visiting various shrines as a hobby, I have acquired the ability to feel the atmosphere of a place.
The same atmosphere as here is when I went to Sumiyoshi Taisha, but the kind of power is a little different? It is a feeling that cannot be expressed in words.
I don't think he's stronger than Konpira Yasui, but his power is too strong and I can't calm down. Of course, Mr. Yasui is a wonderful shrine.

This is my personal impression, but Kyoto people are generally famous for avoiding misfortune here, and Jonangu is here for warding off evil.

I'm sorry that I'm not the type to go to shrines to seek blessings, but this is a good shrine to seek blessings, and it's probably beneficial.
Is the adoration of the people making a place? I don't know if it's Seimei's power, but it's a really special place.

This is the only amulet I wear (excluding the ujigami), and I always get the directional cards from here.
Of course, I always feel your benefit.

Depending on the person, it may look like a shrine for business purposes, but I think it's worth a visit.

I can definitely recommend it.

I have visited you.

Well, there are shrines and temples everywhere in Kyoto.

As soon as you pass through the torii (first torii) from the main street, you will pass through another torii (four shrine gates) to reach the precincts. In the precincts, you can see the statue of Abe no Seimei, a sacred tree, and peaches that ward off evil. The texture didn't look that different from the shrines I usually see, but I often saw the shape of a star (five-pointed star).

I imagined that the building would have many mythological elements, but it is set up as a normal shrine. Review:
The ruins of the residence of Onmyoji Abe no Seimei. When you go to the site, you will be surprised to see a stone monument on the site of Sen no Rikyu's residence.
The torii has a five-pointed star of Onmyodo, claiming that "the Onmyoji is here!", but it is a mystery whether this shrine itself is Shinto or Onmyodo. Compared to touristy shrines in Kyoto, the shrine is smaller than you might imagine.

If you come by car, there is no dedicated parking lot for the shrine, so park at a nearby coin parking and walk for about 5 minutes.

I thought I'd like to visit once, but I wonder if I'll ever visit again...

Author: Tenderfeel
Review:
One bus from Kyoto Station, there is a bus stop right in front, and the name of the bus stop is "Seimei Jinja Mae", so it is very easy to understand. The bus takes less distance to walk than the subway.

The shrine itself isn't that big, and I think it's one of the humblest shrines in Kyoto, but it's crazy because it has a history of 1000 years. Abe no Seimei is enshrined here, so it is a popular spot where people come all the time.
It's the strongest god if you let me ward off evil.

The goshuin is written down, but the goshuin book comes with the written one. It's more expensive than others (3,000 yen), but if you're a fan of Seimei, it's worth it.

Three hundred years, peaches and the toes of the statue must be touched. It is said that it can bring luck to drive away bad luck and invigorate Qi.

All the guards, scenes, and torii in it have pentagram symbols, which are quite special shrines.
You can find more relevant information on the Internet. I highly recommend this small attraction. It can be more interesting when combined with interesting fairy tales.

Author: „ÅÇ„Å®„Çä
Review:
Visited on 16th March 23rd.

It was built on the site of the mansion of Abe no Seimei, an onmyoji in the Heian period.
The enshrined deity is Abe no Seimei, and it is very popular as one of Kyoto's leading power spots.
The "five-pointed star (star-shaped)" is a charm that is used to ward off evil, and can be seen here and there in the precincts.

A five-pointed star was projected from the Shishinmon gate next to the second torii.
Because it is reflected by sunlight, it is not reflected when it is raining or cloudy. Also, it seems that the viewing time is limited.

There are splendid camphor trees, which are sacred trees, and peaches that ward off evil, and many people visited to receive power.
I felt like I was given power not only from Seimei Shrine, but also from such bright and positive people.

Author: „ÅÇ„Åø„Åö
Review:
2023/04/10 Monday

Seimei Shrine came for the first time in many years.
Seimei Shrine came out when I searched for shrines that were compatible with me on the Internet, so I visited after a long time.

After all, it is not famous compared to Kinkakuji, but there were only Japanese people, not foreigners!
Is it because most Japanese people have heard of "Abe no Seimei" or "Onmyoji" at least once?

There were two types of omikuji.
Gogyo mikuji is 300 yen
Seimei fortune is 200 yen
The Seimei fortune slip is a non-inoculated lottery, and when you put your hand on the sensor and wave your hand, a number will appear on the screen! !

Goshuin is cute!

Author: Alexander
Review: Very peaceful shrine. Not so crowded either.

Author: koko -da
Review: When you get off the bus stop in front of Seimei Shrine, the shrine is right in front of you. It's a small shrine, but it's quiet only in this space and it was comfortable to visit. I touched the peach to ward off evil and touched the sacred tree to receive power. Suzu Mamori was the first one when I was looking for an amulet at the conferment office, so I bought it. When I bought it, I didn't notice it and when I got home and took it out of the bag, the sound of the bell was cool and good, unlike the normal bell sound. I carry it with me on my bag to bring good luck. When you buy an amulet, please listen to the sound of the bell.

Author: Jay Tee
Review: This is without exception, my favorite Shinto Shrine. Small but nice, with a few surprises for Westerners.

Author: ÁôΩËìÆ
Review:
The second stop for bicycles, it takes less than 3 minutes to ride from Baifeng Shrine. The bicycles can be parked in the wheel station in the shrine, and about 5 bicycles can be packed.
It's a pity that Zhuyin doesn't have handwriting, and only sells paper copies.

The shrine is not big, but there are many people who come to worship.

Author: Yoshinori Sugiura
Review:
It is far from the subway and train stations, so it might be a good idea to take a bus or take a walk around the nearby temples and shrines before visiting.
The shrine building is small and there is not much to see, but you may be able to feel Abe no Seimei. The time I visited was around 3:00 at the end of May, but it wasn't a good time to take a picture because it was backlit as we headed towards the shrine.
